unificationProblem

Class Unifier

  • java.lang.Object
    • unificationProblem.Unifier

  • public class Unifier
extends java.lang.Object
    The class Unifier handles the left and right part of the unification problem. This means that the unification problem will be splitted in a left and right hand side. For example: p(x,y,x) =? q(f(a),g(b),y) has the left= p(x,y,x) , right= q(f(a),g(b),y)
    Version:
    1.0
    Author:
    Jan-Michael Holzinger & Sophie Hofmanninger

    • Method Detail

      • addOpenCase

        public boolean addOpenCase(Tuple<Function> t)
        Adds a case where the proximity needs to be determined.
        Parameters:
        t - The tuple of functions to add.
        Returns:
        boolean indicating if the case was added.

      • getNextOpenCase

        public Tuple<Function> getNextOpenCase()
        Returns:
        a Tuple of Function whos proximity is to be determined, null if there are no more such.

      • CloseCase

        public boolean CloseCase(Tuple<Function> t,
                         float p)
        Close an open Case.
        Parameters:
        t - the tuple to remove from the list. Note: (a,b) will also be removed, if the method is called with (b,a).
        p - the value to set. Must be in [0,1].
        Returns:
        boolean indicating if the case could be closed.

      • getRight

        public Element getRight()
        Returns:
        the right Element.

        Parameters:
        right - Element to set to the rhs.

      • getLeft

        Returns:
        the left Element.

        public void setLeft(Element left)
        Parameters:

      • getNumberOfFunctions

        public int getNumberOfFunctions()
        Returns:
        the number of functions symbols (and constants).

      • setNumberOfFunctions

        public void setNumberOfFunctions(int numberOfFunctions)
        Parameters:
        numberOfFunctions - the number Of functions symbols to set.

      • getSortedListOfFunctions

        public java.util.ArrayList<Function> getSortedListOfFunctions()
        Returns:
        a list of functions appearing in the unification problem. Note: Constants are treated as 0-ary functions.

      • setSortedListOfFunctions

        public void setSortedListOfFunctions(java.util.ArrayList<Function> sortedListOfFunctions)
        Sets the list of functions.
        Parameters:
        sortedListOfFunctions - the list of functions of this unification problem

      • getProximityRelations

        public Matrix getProximityRelations()
        Returns:
        the proximity relations, represented as a matrix.

      • setProximityRelations

        public void setProximityRelations(Matrix proximityRelations)
        Parameters:
        proximityRelations - the proximity relations to set, represented as a matrix. Note: If the matrix is not a proximity relations Matrix (i.e. all values are in [0,1], and all values on the main diagonal are 1) the matrix will be set to the corresponding unity matrix. Also, function symbols with different arity have to be set to have proximity 0.
